case_name: Crown Aluminium Works v. Bengal Aluminium Workers Union

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 235 of 1956 filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 235 of 1956. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated 29th July 1955 of Labour Appellate Tribunal of India Calcutta in Appeal No. Cal. 182 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: from the judgment and order dated the 29th July, 1955, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Calcutta, in Appeal No. Cal. 182 of 1953.

facts.text: Industrial dispute between appellant Ms. Crown Aluminium Works Belur represented by Jeewanlal 1929 Ltd. and its Workmen represented by Bengal Aluminium Workers Union.

anchor.surface_text: ThiS appeal by special leave arises out of an industrial dispute between the appellant M s. Crown Aluminium Works, Belur, represented by Jeewanlal  1929  Ltd., and its Workmen represented by Bengal Aluminium Workers Union.

facts.text: Government of West Bengal referred thirteen matters to Shri S. K. Niyogi Sixth Industrial Tribunal by order dated July 31 1952 under s. 10 Industrial Disputes Act 1947.

anchor.surface_text: By their order dated July 31, 1952, the Government of West Bengal referred thirteen matters for adjudication to Shri S. K. Niyogi who was appointed to companystitute the Sixth Industrial Tribunal for adjudication under s. 10 of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

facts.text: Sixth Industrial Tribunal pronounced award on October 9 1953 after considering pleas evidence and financial position of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The learned adjudicator companysidered the pleas raised, and the evidence led, by the parties before him, investigated into the financial position of the appellant and pronounced his award on October 9, 1953, on all matters referred to him.

facts.text: Both parties aggrieved by Sixth Tribunal award leading to two cross appeals disposed by Labour Appellate Tribunal on July 11 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Both parties were aggrieved by the award and that led to two cross appeals. On July 11, 1955, the Labour Appellate Tribunal disposed of these appeals by a companysolidated order.

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal revised wage structure constituted by original tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The main grievance which Mr. Sen has made before us on behalf of the appellant is in respect of the revision made by the Appellate Tribunal in the wage structure which was companystituted by the original tribunal.

facts.text: First Omnibus Engineering Tribunal award published June 30 1948 governing appellant.

anchor.surface_text: This tribunal gave a companyprehensive award which was published on June 30, 1948. The appellant was a party to these adjudication proceedings and was governed by the said award.

facts.text: Second engineering tribunal award published September 21 1950 increasing dearness allowance.

anchor.surface_text: This award was published on September 21, 1950. By this award the dearness allowance fixed by the first tribunal was increased on the ground of rise in the companyt of living index

facts.text: Minor industrial dispute referred to Shri G. Palit by West Bengal Government order dated November 24 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile, a minor industrial dispute arose between the appellant and its workmen and it was referred to the arbitration of Shri G. Palit by the Government of West Bengal by their order dated November 24, 1950.

facts.text: Shri Palit awarded one anna per day increment to workers in 1950 payable as arrears to workmen on roll at end of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Palit, therefore, granted the workmens demands by allowing one anna per day increment though he frankly companyfessed that this was number based on any actual calculation. He accordingly, directed the appellant to pay the arrears within one month

facts.text: Appellant issued notice on March 28 1952 proposing reduction of factory hours from 47 to 40 facility bonus by 3 as. per day temporary dearness allowance for salaried by 10% effective June 1 1952 due to financial setback.

anchor.surface_text: On March 28, 1952, the appellant issued a numberice to its workmen proposing to make certain modifications. The numberice indicated that a reduction of the factory hours from 47 to 40 would be made, the facility bonus would be reduced by 3 as. per day and temporary dearness allowance for the salaried workers would be similarly reduced by 10 of the then current rates.

facts.text: Union opposed changes joint discussions held June 2 and June 26 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The Union opposed these changes. A joint discussion was then arranged on June 2 and June 26, 1952.

facts.text: Further economy measures notice dated May 30 1952 reduction facility bonus 6 as. per day withdrawal two hours concession discharge rolling mills workers.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that further economy measures were introduced for discussion between the parties by the numberice dated May 30, 1952 These further economy measures related to the reduction of the facility bonus by a further amount of 6 as. per day, withdrawal of two hours companycession of special bonus and discharge of workers of the rolling mills department.

facts.text: Appellant implemented reductions by notice June 27 1952 effective June 1 1952 withdrew two hours concession July 1 1952 discharged rolling mills workers August 1 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Since joint companysultations did number lead to any agreement the appellant b its numberice dated June 27, 1952, intimated to the workers that the reduction of working hours and in the facility bonus and dearness allowance as numberified on March 28, 1952, would be brought into operation from June 1, 1952.

facts.text: Joint conference July 4 1952 with Labour Commissioner failed.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter a joint companyrence of the appellant and its workmen was held on July 4, 1952. The intervention of the Labour Commissioner was number effective as the proposals made by him to resolve the dispute between the parties amicably were number acceptable to the parties.

facts.text: Appellant discharged 52 rolling mills workmen with 14 days notice pay retrenched 227 other workers from July 26 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereupon discharged the workmen of the rolling mills department, 52 in number, with 14 days numberice pay and retrenched other 227 workers of various categories as from July 26, 1952, with a similar numberice pay.

facts.text: Sixth Industrial Tribunal held two hours concession facility bonus food concession as bounty withdrawable revised wage structure per 1948 1950 awards.

anchor.surface_text: The Sixth Industrial Tribunal companysidered the financial position of the appellant and revised and reconstituted the wage structure and the dearness allowance in the light of the Omnibus Engineering Awards in West Bengal published in 1948 and 1950. The tribunal hold that the two hours companycession, facility bonus and the food companycession were in the nature of bounty gratuitously paid by the appellant and as such they companyld be withdrawn by the appellant at its pleasure.

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal held concessional payments enjoyed long time as of right part of basic wages dearness allowance term of service convention not to reduce emoluments modified wage structure for existing workmen.

anchor.surface_text: The view that the Appellate Tribunal has taken is that these so-called companycessional payments have been enjoyed by the workmen for a pretty long time as of right and as part of their basic wages and dearness allowance and as such they have become a term of the companyditions of their service.

facts.text: Appellant took over aluminium unit from Americans on August 9 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The present unit of the aluminium industry which was originally started by the Americans was taken over by the appellant from the Americans on August 9, 1951.

facts.text: Rolling mills department closed permanently February 1952 rolling mills workmen discharged July 15 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The management was thus companypelled to close down the rolling mills permanently in February, 1952. As we have already mentioned, the workmen employed in the rolling mills were ultimately discharged on July 15,1952.

facts.text: Both tribunals found appellants economic position not too bright manufacturing cost exceeded sale price in 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Both the tribunals have examined these figures and have companye to the companyclusion that the economic position of the appellant on the whole was numbere too bright. Fall in the sale of utensils was numbericeable during these years

facts.text: Two hours concession introduced August 1946 to compensate time rate workers for reduction in hours due to Factories Act.

anchor.surface_text: Prior to the new Factories Act, the appellants workmen worked on an average for 59 hours of work made up of the usual 54 hours of work and overtime. After the Factories Act came into force, the working hours had to be reduced but in order to companypensate the time. rate workers for reduction in their wages, the management added to the daily earnings of such workers the wages for two hours.

facts.text: Facility bonus introduced April 1945 revised upward linked to basic wages paid prior to June 1952 at 6 to 12 as. per day.

anchor.surface_text: In April, 1945, facility bonus had been introduced at 3 as. per day for workers getting basic wages equal to or less than 10 as. per day and 4 as. per day for workers whose basic wages were over 10 as. per day It appears that this facility bonus was revised from time to time in the upward direction, and it used to be paid prior to June 1952 at a graduated scale linked to the basic wages in slabs varying from 6 as. to 12 as. per day.

facts.text: Food concession introduced to workers employed prior to 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Besides, the appellant introduced food companycession to workers employed prior to 1951.

issues.text: Can the wage structure fixed in a given industry be never revised to the prejudice of its workmen?

anchor.surface_text: Can the wage structure fixed in a given industry be never revised to the prejudice of its workmen? Considered as a general question in the abstract it must be answered in favour of Mr. Sen. We do not think it would be correct to say that in no conceivable circumstances can the wage structure be revised to the prejudice of workmen,

issues.text: Whether the Labour Appellate Tribunal was in error in assuming that it has been the convention in industrial adjudications not to reduce the existing emoluments of the workmen to their prejudice in any case?

anchor.surface_text: For the appellant Mr. Sen has contended that the Labour Appellate Tribunal was in error in assuming that it has been the convention in industrial adjudications not to reduce the existing emoluments of the workmen to their prejudice in any case. He contends that just as the rise in the cost of living index or similar relevant factors may justify the revision of the wage structure in favour of the workmen,

issues.text: What is the true character of the concessional payments made by the appellant to its workmen (two hours concession, facility bonus, food concession)?
Whether the result of the award leads to two scales of wage structure, one for existing workmen and one for new entrants, and if justified?

anchor.surface_text: There is one more point which may be mentioned before we part with this case. Mr. Sen incidentally argued that the result of the award passed by the Labour Appellate Tribunal is that there will be two scales of wage structure, one for those who are already in the employment of the appellant and the other for the new entrants.

anchor.surface_text: industrial adjudication takes into account several principles such as, for instance, the principle of comparable wages, productivity of the trade or industry, cost of living and ability of the industry to pay.

holdings.text: There is no rigid and inexorable convention that the wage structure once fixed by industrial tribunals can never be changed to the prejudice of workmen.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects absolute convention; analogous to upward revisions for cost of living; balances labor-capital interests subject to merits.

holdings.text: No industry has a right to exist unless it is able to pay its workmen at least a bare minimum wage; wage structure cannot be revised below minimum wage.

anchor.surface_text: No industry has a right to exist unless it is able to pay its workmen at least a bare minimum wage. It is quite likely that in under-developed countries,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Welfare state principle; prevents starvation wages; absolute floor despite financial distress.

holdings.text: If wage structure is above bare minimum, employer can claim downward revision if case made out on merits, considering financials, retrenchment, duration of distress.

anchor.surface_text: Can the wage structure fixed in a given industry be never revised to the prejudice of its workmen? Considered as a general question in the abstract it must be answered in favour of Mr. Sen. We do not think it would be correct to say that in no conceivable circumstances can the wage structure be revised to the prejudice of workmen,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies wage categories (living/fair/minimum); weighs relevant factors like ability to pay, productivity; avoids disharmony or industry collapse.

holdings.text: Concessional payments (two hours concession, facility bonus, food concession) form part of basic wage and dearness allowance as term of service, not bounty.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Examines genesis, duration, evidence (Shah's testimony), prior conduct, pleadings; consistent treatment as wage components.

holdings.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal's award not vitiated; relied on financial improvement post-retrenchment and other factors besides convention; no interference warranted.
holdings.reasoning_summary: LAT considered multiple factors (retrenchment benefits, cost of living data insufficiency); court slow to interfere absent legal error.

holdings.text: Industrial adjudication considers principles like comparable wages, productivity, cost of living, ability to pay to constitute wage structures categorized as living, fair, minimum wage.

anchor.surface_text: In achieving this immediate objective, industrial adjudication takes into account several principles such as, for instance, the principle of comparable wages, productivity of the trade or industry, cost of living and ability of the industry to pay. The application of these and other relevant principles leads to the constitution of different categories of wage structures.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Surveys objectives of welfare state adjudication; applies to facts for balanced wage fixation.

Holding h3 supports the fair wage concept by articulating that structures above minimum wage are subject to downward revision on merits, matching c8's description of fair wage as revisable based on merits.
h3 specializes h1 by detailing merits-based conditions for revision permitted under h1

anchor.surface_text: Can the wage structure fixed in a given industry be never revised to the prejudice of its workmen? We do not think it would be correct to say that in no conceivable circumstances can the wage structure be revised to the prejudice of workmen,
